progress_notes.subjective: Patient reports sharp abdominal pain that began 12 hours prior to admission, with worsening intensity over time. Reports associated nausea and mild fatigue. Denies vomiting or diarrhea.
progress_notes.objective: Vital signs stable; abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the lower right quadrant with mild guarding. Mild fever observed (37.8°C). CBC shows white blood cell count slightly elevated at 10.2 x10^9/L.
progress_notes.assessment: Suspected acute appendicitis. Patient's presentation aligns with classic symptoms, with tenderness localized in the right lower quadrant and elevated WBC.
progress_notes.plan: Order imaging (CT abdomen) to confirm diagnosis. Begin IV fluids and administer analgesics for pain control. Monitor vital signs and review lab results for any additional abnormalities.

progress_notes.subjective: Patient reports slight improvement in pain following initial analgesic dose but continues to experience discomfort. Appetite remains poor, though nausea has decreased.
progress_notes.objective: Vital signs remain stable. Abdominal tenderness persists, though less severe than on admission. Lab results show WBC trending down to 9.5 x10^9/L. CT scan confirms acute appendicitis.
progress_notes.assessment: Confirmed diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Patient showing some improvement but continues to require pain management.
progress_notes.plan: Schedule patient for appendectomy within the next 24 hours. Continue IV fluids, maintain pain management, and monitor for any signs of infection or worsening symptoms.

progress_notes.subjective: Patient reports significant reduction in pain post-surgery. Reports feeling more comfortable and able to move without severe discomfort.
progress_notes.objective: Incision sites appear clean and dry with no signs of infection. Vital signs stable. Patient is alert and ambulates with minimal assistance.
progress_notes.assessment: Post-operative recovery is progressing as expected with no complications observed.
progress_notes.plan: Continue monitoring incision sites for signs of infection. Gradually transition to oral medications for pain management. Encourage mobility and deep breathing exercises to prevent complications.

surgery_notes: Appendectomy performed successfully via laparoscopic approach. Surgical team reports no immediate complications; estimated blood loss was minimal at approximately 20 ml. The appendix was inflamed but intact upon removal. Post-operative checks indicated stable vitals, with no adverse reactions to anesthesia observed.

Follow-up surgery assessment on post-op day two: incision sites inspected and found to be clean, dry, and intact without signs of infection or discharge. Patient reports mild discomfort at the site but denies severe pain or fever. Dressing changed, and patient advised on post-operative care and hygiene to prevent infection.

On post-op day three, patient reports steady improvement in pain levels, which are managed effectively with prescribed analgesics. Surgical wounds are healing well, with no redness or swelling noted. Patient instructed on how to care for the incision sites at home.

admission_note.subjective: 67-year-old female presents with acute onset of abdominal pain localized to the right lower quadrant. The pain started approximately 12 hours prior to admission and has been worsening. Reports nausea but denies vomiting, diarrhea, or recent trauma. Patient expresses concern about the cause of the pain and is anxious about potential surgery.
admission_note.objective: Vital signs upon admission: temperature 37.8°C, heart rate 88 bpm, blood pressure 135/85 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation 96%. Physical exam reveals tenderness and guarding in the right lower quadrant. Initial lab work shows mildly elevated white blood cell count (10.2 x10^9/L), with other labs within normal range.
admission_note.assessment: Probable acute appendicitis given location of pain, tenderness on exam, and elevated WBC count. Differential diagnosis includes ovarian cyst rupture or gastrointestinal issues, though less likely.
admission_note.plan: Order abdominal CT to confirm appendicitis. Start IV fluids and administer analgesics as needed for pain. Maintain NPO (nothing by mouth) status in preparation for potential surgery. Monitor vital signs and reassess after imaging results.

discharge_note: Patient was discharged in stable condition following a successful appendectomy. All vital signs were within normal limits at discharge, and patient exhibited no signs of infection or complications. Discharge instructions included wound care, dietary recommendations, and warning signs of infection to monitor, such as fever or unusual discharge from the incision sites. Pain medication was prescribed for home use, and patient advised to avoid heavy lifting for 4-6 weeks. Follow-up appointment scheduled in two weeks to monitor recovery progress and remove sutures if healing continues as expected.
medication_history: Atenolol 50mg daily for hypertension. Patient has been on this medication for over 5 years with good control over blood pressure.
Ibuprofen 200mg as needed for mild pain relief, particularly for joint pain due to mild osteoarthritis.
Metformin 500mg twice daily for management of type 2 diabetes, which has been controlled with this regimen for the past 3 years.
Paracetamol 500mg as needed, taken in low frequency primarily for occasional headaches.
family_history: The patient's mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in her late 60s and also had hypertension. Father suffered from ischemic heart disease and passed away at age 72. One sibling diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and managed with lifestyle modifications and medication.
nursing_note: Upon admission, the patient was provided with IV fluids and pain management. Patient reports moderate pain relief and is resting comfortably. Vital signs stable, and she is monitored every 4 hours.

On the morning following surgery, the patient was assisted in ambulation with minimal help. Reports mild pain at the incision site, which is expected post-operatively. Patient tolerated clear liquids and showed signs of gradual improvement.

During evening rounds, patient appeared calm and was able to ambulate to the restroom without assistance. Pain medication provided as scheduled. Vital signs remain within normal range, and IV fluids discontinued as per medical orders.
